title: 110_hr2967
content: The "Campaign Taxpayer Reimbursement Act of 2007" prohibits the use of federal funds for travel that includes political campaign or fundraising events. The "Campaign Taxpayer Reimbursement Act of 2007" prohibits federal funds from being used for travel by covered executive branch officials if they attend political campaign or fundraising events, unless reimbursed by the candidate's campaign committee or political party committee. The "Campaign Taxpayer Reimbursement Act of 2007" prohibits federal funds from being used for travel by covered executive branch officials if they attend political campaign events. Reimbursement for travel costs, including using an aircraft, is limited to the commercial charter rate for transportation accommodating campaign-related travelers. The "Campaign Taxpayer Reimbursement Act of 2007" prohibits federal funds from being used for travel by covered executive branch officials attending political campaign events. Reimbursement for travel costs, including aircraft use, is limited to the commercial charter rate for transportation accommodating campaign-related travelers. For travel undertaken by the President or Vice President for political events involving multiple sponsors, reimbursement allocation is determined by regulations established by the Federal Election Commission. The section exempts salary payments to covered executive branch officials from the restrictions. It also applies to funds used for travel by Members of the House of Representatives, except for funds in their Representational Allowance. The definitions provided in this section apply to the regulations. The section defines "covered executive branch official" as the President, Vice President, and certain agency heads, and "designated post of duty" as the White House. It also defines "political campaign event" for these officials. The term "political fundraising event" refers to any gathering where funds are raised to support a candidate or political party, including events where a donation is required to attend. The term "political committee" is defined in the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. The term "principal campaign committee" is defined in the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971, with specific guidelines for candidates running for State or local public office. SEC. 3 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require reimbursement of certain state and local government security costs by campaigns. Sec. 325 mandates reimbursement of security costs incurred by states or local governments for providing services at political events by the respective campaign committees, except for events attended by the President or Vice President for their own campaigns. The section mandates reimbursement of security costs for political events attended by the President or Vice President for their own campaigns. Definitions for terms are provided in the Campaign Taxpayer Reimbursement Act of 2007. The Act and its amendments will apply to travel undertaken after the enactment date.
